Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Heat Transfer in Granular Flows: Understanding Similarities and Differences with Molecular Fluids

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed study aims at understanding why particles in fluid might or might not enhance heat transfer for surfaces. The investigator will examine results from models and experiments to shed lights on existing conflicting work. Part of the proposed plan is to engage undergraduates and high school students in separate, small research projects aimed at the magazine Annals of Improbable Research (AIR) with an editorial board that includes several Nobel Prize winners. AIR has a tagline "research that makes people laugh and then think," designed to motivate a broader range of students to gain experience in scientific research, as well as a means for making science more accessible and exciting for the greater public.

The PI proposes to develop numerical models and experimentally validate the numerical models (and the associated hypotheses) for application of granular flows in enhancing heat transfer during two-phase flows. The existing experimental results in the literature perplexedly indicates heat flux does not scaling monotonously with Peclet number. The proposed research aims at resolving such a contradiction and is thus intriguing. This work builds on recent research involving multi-phase flows but adds complex approaches involving granules with different shapes, surface roughness, slip velocities, and flow instabilities. The hypotheses to be tested are: (1) the discrepancy in existing data sets in the literature for macro-level quantities (heat transfer coefficient) can be traced to micro-level characteristics, such as surface roughness and tomography; (2) an increase in particle mobility can lead to reduced heat transfer due to reduced contact time with boundary; (3) the presence of flow instabilities may attenuate heat transfer due to increased particle mobility and thus decreased contact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major focus of the proposed research is on heat transfer in dense particulate systems where conduction dominates. Conductive heat transfer in gas-solid systems can occur via two mechanisms: direct conduction and indirect conduction. Direct conduction occurs across the particle-particle or particle-wall contact area, whereas indirect conduction occurs through the interstitial fluid surrounding the particle near the contact area. For particles having a relatively small contact area as well as a smaller thermal conductivity, such as glass, sand, steel, etc., indirect conduction dominates over direct conduction. The project is mainly focused on the indirect conduction mechanism. 

Prediction of macroscopic behavior of granular materials relies on the understanding of microscopic interactions. Hence, in the current effort, a detailed characterization of microscopic particle properties, such as particle surface roughness and shape, are carried out, which has not been reported before. The above particle-scale properties are further isolated one at a time to experimentally explore the effects of each on conductive heat transfer.  Soda lime glass particles were used in all experiments. To modify the surface roughness, a set of glass particles were base etched for ~1 hour to produce smooth particles. Surface roughness of both the modified and the original particles were quantified via atomic force microscopy (AFM), which shows that the base etching process reduced the asperity height of the particles to half of its original size. We hypothesize that rough particles (larger asperity height) will increase the particle-particle (or wall) separation distance, and thus will decrease conductive heat transfer. To alter the particle shape, spherical glass particles were crushed in a hydraulic press to obtain more angular particle. Sphericity, which is defined as the ratio of equivalent sphere, projected area diameter to the equivalent sphere, projected perimeter diameter, was determined for both the spherical and the crushed particles by analyzing the microscopic images. Here our hypothesis is that angular (flat) particles will have better heat transfer compared to their spherical counterparts due to more contact area between particle-particle or particle-wall.

Static-bed experiments were designed to establish the effects of particle size, surface roughness, and shape on conductive heat transfer, particularly on wall-to-particle conduction. To assess the validity of a state-of-the-art indirect conduction theory, the experimental heat transfer coefficient is compared with computational fluid dynamics (CFD) – discrete element simulation (DEM) simulation outputs which utilizes the theory.  The heat transfer coefficient for the smooth particles from the experiments are found to be 16% higher than that for the rough particles, which supports our original hypothesis. Furthermore, the percentage change in the heat transfer coefficient to the change in surface roughness is in agreement with the CFD–DEM predictions. However, the heat transfer coefficient values for all the three sizes of glass particles differ from the simulation results. Our hypothesis for the above discrepancy is that assuming uniform temperature distribution inside the particles which is inherent to CFD-DEM simulations could lead to over-predictions of the heat rate compared to the experiments. To test this hypothesis, the theoretical analysis carried out for a single glass particle shows that significant temperature gradients exist inside the particle. By considering the position dependent temperature of the particle surface, as hypothesized, the isothermal particle assumption is found to over-predict the heat rate. Hence, the Biot number (Bi), which is the ratio of resistance to heat transfer inside the particle to resistance to heat transfer through the interstitial fluid, needs further evaluation to estimate a critical value below which the isothermal particle assumption can yield accurate predictions. Bi for the glass particles used in the experiment are found to be 0.3, 0.32, and 0.35. For robustness, experiments and CFD-DEM simulations were also carried out with steel particles which has a relatively small Bi than glass, i.e., 0.01. The results show good agreement between experiments and CFD-DEM predictions. Furthermore, a theoretical analysis suggests that the isothermal particle assumption can lead to certain over-prediction of the heat rate from the indirect conduction theory depending upon the particle Bi. Based upon the analysis, a critical Bi = 0.015 is proposed for indirect-conduction-dominated systems for which percentage error in the prediction is less than 10%. 

Experiments carried out for the non-spherical particles reveal a counter-intuitive trend. The preliminary results indicate that spherical particles show better heat transfer than their non-spherical counterparts. The results obtained directs the future work in this area to further investigate the packing structure of non-spherical particles compared to spherical particles which could be one of the reasons for such a trend.

Overall, the experiments and simulations carried out in this work establish the effects of particle-scale roughness on wall-to-particle heat transfer, and provide experimental validation for a state-of-the-art heat transfer theory. Hence, the current effort is essentially a step forward to establish a better understanding of particulate heat transfer.
